answers: “The Diamond as Big as the Ritz”
parts: Name this novella in which John T. Unger goes to the middle of nowhere in Montana to visit his classmate, whose father owns the title object.
“The Diamond as Big as the Ritz” was included in the collection Tales of the Jazz Age, written by this Lost Generation American author.

Fitzgerald wrote this essay, the first in a group of three that were published in Esquire magazine in 1936. It starts with the pessimistic quote, “Of course all life is a process of breaking down,” reflecting the author’s mental state at the time.
Name these cytoplasmic protrusions from the cell body of a neuron, which transmit electrical signals received by dendrites.
A giant axon a millimeter thick in the longfin inshore species of this animal was famously studied by Hodgkin and Huxley. That axon in this creature controls its water jet propulsion system.
The longest axons in the human body are those of this nerve, which runs from the base of the spinal cord through the buttock to the big toe.

answers: the Second Coming of Jesus [or the Second Advent; prompt on the day of the Lord]
parts: Name this event described by the Greek word parousia, in which the Messiah returns “like a thief in the night.”

Dispensationalists believe that after the rapture and a period of tribulation, Jesus will reign on Earth for this many years before the final judgment and the establishment of the New Heaven and Earth.

The length of the tribulation is usually interpreted to be seven years by the “Seventy Weeks Prophecy” in this book of the Bible, in which Gabriel speaks to the title prophet while in exile in Babylon.

answers: The School of Athens [or Scuola di Atene]
parts: Name this fresco from the Italian Renaissance that depicts various philosophers.
The School of Athens is the masterpiece of this Renaissance artist who also created Transfiguration and Saint George and the Dragon.
In the center foreground of The School of Athens, Heraclitus in a purple cloak is depicted in the guise of this other Renaissance painter and architect as he writes at a desk.
This lawsuit, brought to the Supreme Court in 1984, held that the burning of the American flag was a protected form of speech.
This bill, passed by a Federalist-dominated Congress under John Adams, sought to forbid “false, scandalous, or malicious writing.”

In one of the earliest cases addressing freedom of speech, this German-American printer was accused of libel in 1733 after criticizing colonial governor William Cosby in his newspaper, The New York Weekly Journal.

answers: The Day the Leader was Killed <Jin>
parts: Name this group of novels that follow the three generations of the Abd al-Jawad family, with book titles named after real-life streets in the author’s hometown.
This Egyptian author wrote the Cairo Trilogy as well as the novel Children of Gebelawi, a novel that resulted in him getting stabbed in the neck by Muslim extremists 35 years after its publication.
Mahfouz wrote about the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in this aptly-titled novel, which is told from the point of view of the Muhtashimi family.

This man’s forces were responsible for the first foreign invasion of England in 55 BC. That invasion by this man was justified on the grounds that enemies opposing his conquest of Gaul in 58 BC had retreated across the English Channel.

The Battle of Quiberon Bay in this war stymied France’s plans to invade England by crossing the English Channel through a devastation of French naval forces. During this war, William Pitt the Elder acted as Great Britain’s war minister.

During World War II, a mass exodus of over 300,000 British troops was executed from the French port of Dunkirk during this operation. Over 800 ships, many of which were civilian owned, executed this operation.
Ascorbic acid is the name usually given for the vitamin known by this letter. This vitamin is found in citrus fruits and can help prevent scurvy.
Deficiency of this vitamin can cause a medical condition in which the eye fails to produce tears. It is found in fish, dairy products, and meat, and has the chemical name retinol.
Vitamin B9 has this chemical name. This vitamin can help prevent anemia, and it is found in many leafy vegetables, leading to its Latin root, the word for “leaf.”
Name this often adapted character who closed his eyes and sang to prove his worth, and was abducted by a fox. He is the protagonist of The Nun’s Priest’s Tale.
Along with The Nun’s Priest’s Tale, Chaucer included this story in The Canterbury Tales. This tale tells of Palamon and Arcite [AR-see-tay], who fight for Emily’s love.
John Fletcher and William Shakespeare wrote this adaptation of the Knight’s Tale. In it, Palamon and Arcite fought for Creon, until Theseus defeated and imprisoned them.

Study of the language of the Pirahãs has caused many to reevaluate the Universal Grammar proposed by this MIT linguist, since it does not contain numbers, past or future tenses, recursion, or other supposedly ubiquitous concepts included in this man’s work Syntactic Structures.

The Pirahã language is believed to have either ten or eleven of these fundamental units of sound that do not convey meaning by themselves. Those consist of three vowels and either seven or eight consonants.

In transcribing the Pirahã language, an “x” is used to denote this phoneme that is produced by abruptly obstructing airflow through the entrance of the vocal folds. In English, this phoneme occurs in the interjection “uh-oh” and can be used in place of a “t” in the words “cat” and “button.”
Name these objects, the concave types of which bulge inward and cause light to diverge.
All rays of light entering a lens parallel to the optic axis will exit the lens in a line intersecting this point.

This type of lens has its surface broken up by narrow, stepped rings that save space and mass to produce shorter focal lengths and larger apertures. It is often used in lighthouses, and its namesake French physicist coined the term linear polarization.
This country’s flag is the only one in the world that is not a quadrilateral. It has a blue border and a crimson background in the shape of two stacked pennons.
From 1977 to 2011, this country’s flag consisted solely of the color green. This country’s current flag has red, black, and green horizontal stripes with a white star and crescent in the center.

In addition to Guatemala, this country’s flag is the only other one in the world to feature a firearm. It has a horizontal tricolor of green, black, and yellow with a red triangle on the left housing an AK-47.
Name this Western musical tradition that gained prominence in the ninth and tenth centuries and that consists of monophonic, unaccompanied singing of the Roman Rite.

Each work of Gregorian chant can be classified by this pitch organization scheme that includes eight categories based on the pitches used, the final, and the reciting tone. They can be either authentic or plagal and include the Hypomixolydian and the Phrygian.
This term refers to the refrain of a Psalm alternated with its verses. The style of chant named for this term consists of two choirs singing in alternation.
Name this French poet who wrote the poetry collection Saturnine Poems. He was a lover of another French poet, Arthur Rimbaud.

This Verlaine poem was included in Saturnine Poems and was used to send messages during World War II. Specifically, its first line, “wound my heart with a monotonous languor,” was used to signal that Operation Overlord would start in 48 hours.

The third section of T. S. Eliot’s “The Waste Land” contains the line “Et, ô ces voix d'enfants chantant dans la coupole!” [“et, oh say vwah den-fahn shan-tahn dahns la coo-pole”], which is taken from the last line of this Verlaine poem about the titular knight.
Name this jazz style characterized by complex chord progressions and a really fast tempo, exemplified by Dizzy Gillespie’s “Shaw 'Nuff.”
This leading musician of the bebop era played alto saxophone on “Shaw ‘Nuff.” He is also known for his pieces “Crazeology,” “Ko-Ko,” and “Ornithology.”

The chord structure of “Crazeology” consists of the namesake “changes” based on this song by George Gershwin. It consists of a thirty-two bar A-B-B-A form with the chords I, vi, ii, V [“one, six, two, five”] followed by a circle of fourths.
Name this thought experiment in which you have to decide whom to kill by a switchtrack for the namesake runaway vehicle.

If you have the choice to switch a track for a runaway trolley heading towards a group of five murderers so that it instead kills one innocent bystander, proponents of this ethical theory like Henry Sidgwick would say that it is obligatory to switch the track regardless of innocence, because five is greater than one.

The choice to push a fat man into the track to stop the trolley and save five lives at the expense of one explores this principle, which states that you may take action which has bad side effects, but deliberately intending harm is wrong even if for good causes.

answers: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto [do not accept or prompt on Tsuki]
parts: When Izanagi washed his face, Susano’o was born from his nose, Amaterasu from his left eye, and this moon god was born from his right eye.
The three deities also had an influence on the three imperial regalia of Japan, which consist of The Grass Cutting Sword, the Eight-Sided Mirror, and one of these objects.
Another Japanese deity with jewels was the god Ryujin. In Japanese mythology, Ryujin famously used his jewels to do this action.

answers: theory of continental drift [do not accept or prompt on plate tectonics because Wegener was only involved in the theory of continental drift]
parts: Name this geologic theory formulated by Alfred Wegener that states the Earth’s crust is composed of plates that move relative to each other over time.
These zones occur as a result of tensional tectonic forces, creating grabens and half-grabens as well as forming new crustal material.
This large region in East Africa runs almost four thousand miles and is an aulacogen, a rift zone formed when one plate in a triple junction is overtaken by the other two plates.

answers: Henri Philippe Benoni Omer Joseph Pétain [or Marshal Pétain]
parts: Name this Nazi German puppet state in southern France, named for the small spa town that acted as its capital.

This man was Vichy France’s head of state for the five years of its existence. Known to some as the Lion of Verdun, this man was hailed as a national hero despite being sentenced to life imprisonment for treason.

French North Africa, a possession of Vichy France, was invaded in 1942 by a combined British and American force in this operation. This operation was the second advance into Axis-occupied North Africa following the defeat at the Battle of El Alamein.
Name this country, which was colonized by Spain from 1565-1898 out of the city of Manila.

During World War II, tens of thousands of Filipino and American P.O.W.s were sent on a death march named for this Philippine peninsula. Over ten thousand Filipino P.O.W.s were killed on this death march.
Following twenty years of rule by Ferdinand Marcos, this woman became the first female president of the Philippines in 1986. She is best known for reinstating a bicameral congress in the Philippines.

answers: pierogies [do not accept or prompt on dumpling]
KFC [accept Kentucky Fried Chicken, but if they mess up don’t take it] <Yoshida>
parts: In Poland, this type of dumpling is a Christmas staple. Krakow has a yearly festival celebrating this food item.
Smalahove is a Western Norwegian dish eaten before Christmas. It is a dish made from the head of one of these animals.
In Japan, rather than cooking at home, many families get food from this restaurant to celebrate.
